What is the relationship between an ID and a currency in Verus?
In Verus, an ID of a specific name is the only one that can create a currency of the same name, and it can only do so once. The controller of the ID has control over the currency.

an ID of the same name. The controller of this ID is the only one who can create a currency of that name, and they can only do so once.
So, let's hypothetically assume I have 3 IDs, one named gold@, one named mycoin@, and one named mike@. I would like to have one currency, gold@,
that I somehow launch in a way that maps it in a way that can be widely trusted to a specific, auditable store of gold.
I also would like to launch a token called mycoin@, which is something like a Kickstarter, where a business, "my", offers to attribute the coins some utility or product value if the purchase exceeds a certain level.
First, I could define the currency "gold" as follows:
```
./verus -chain=VRSCTEST definecurrency '{"name":"gold","options":96,"currencies":["vrsctest"],"conversions":[0.01],"minpreconversion":[1000],"preallocation":[{"mike@":50000000.00000000}]}'
```
of course, since this is a test currency, I send myself some to start. The identity of the currency must be funded with at least 10 VRSCTEST before sending the transaction returned from this command to
initiate a currency launch that will start at 50 blocks from when it was made (default), and that must have 1000 VRSCTEST preconverted at 0.01 VRSCTEST per GOLD in order to launch.
all of this happens as part of the mining process, since mining the blocks that launch a currency earn the 0.025% conversion fees of participation
in the launch, converting VRSCTEST to GOLD. I could send the following command before the block where GOLD token launches.
After it launches, the only way at present to create new tokens is with a centralized issuance option. To convert VRSCTEST to GOLD, you could issue the command:
```
./verus -chain=VRSCTEST sendcurrency "*" '[{"address":"mike@","convertto":"gold","preconvert":1,"amount":100}]'
```
that would effectively park my conversion until the token launches, at which point, I will either

How can I define a currency in Verus, and what are some of the important properties I need to set?

To define a currency in Verus, you can use the `definecurrency` command. Some important properties you need to set include:
- `name`: the name of the currency
- `options`: an integer that configures the currency's properties
- `currencies`: an array of currencies that the new currency can be converted to
- `conversions`: an array of conversion ratios between the new currency and each currency in the `currencies` array
- `minpreconversion`: the minimum amount of the new currency that must be preconverted to launch the currency
- `preallocation`: an array of IDs and their initial allocations of the new currency

What happens when I define a currency in Verus, and what needs to happen before it launches?

When you define a currency in Verus, it does not launch immediately. The identity of the currency must be funded with at least 10 VRSCTEST before sending the transaction returned from the `definecurrency` command. The currency will then launch 50 blocks after the transaction is mined, as part of the mining process. The launch requires a minimum amount of VRSCTEST to be preconverted to the new currency at a specified conversion rate.

How can I convert VRSCTEST to a new currency in Verus, such as GOLD?

To convert VRSCTEST to a new currency in Verus, such as GOLD, you can use the `sendcurrency` command. You need to specify the address, the currency to convert to, the preconvert amount, and the amount of VRSCTEST to convert. The conversion will be parked until the new currency launches, at which point you will either receive the converted amount of the new currency or have your VRSCTEST returned.
